ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Part design, SolidWorks CAD, manufacturing processes, mechanics of materials, etc.
Statics, strength & def, CAD
solidworks, analyzing stresses/strains
The course introduced me to fundamental areas related to the designing aspect of mechanical engineering.
I got a solid introduction to topics in mechanical engineering and the mechanical design process. I was also introduced to SolidWorks for the first time.
learned about the different kinds of manufacturing processes, free body diagrams and statics, and stress/torsion/deflection
This course gives a sneak peek of many other mechanical engineering courses in the future of the major so has some statics, materials science, and manufacturing aspects.
Learned how to use cads and solid works.

I learned the basics of mechanical design starting from different view, projections, and dimensioning of engineering drawings. I developed knowledge and ability to use SOLIDWORKS through various labs. Because of COVID we did not get to go to the shop, but we did go over statics, free-body diagrams, material properties and stresses.
An intro to mechanical engineering, including drawings, CAD, statics, materials, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Gave an overview of required materials for MechE in a deep enough way to lay a proper foundation, but not too deep as to be too difficult for an introductory design class.

Strengths: good intro, all around course
Weaknesses: lectures were sometimes unclear & slow

I liked how the labs were adapted for a virtual environment, lectures were very relaxed

I tend to like learning from a textbook and this course didn't have that so it would have been nice to have some more organized lecture slides/notes uploaded to Canvas for the second half of the course
The course explained all fundamental areas with equal importance and drew connections which helped me understand them better.
This course expected/assumed some prior knowledge of mechanical engineering which at times made it difficult to fully understand the material.
If you take MENG 280, the second two-thirds of the course is just a general review. In the first third of the course, we went over everything too quickly.

The labs in this course were very engaging and the assignments were interesting but not overly-long, which I appreciated. I felt like this course was taught at a pace that expected us to have some experience with material properties, but I came in having none and it took me a little while to get comfortable with the topic because of that.
The course is a little bit scattered but that is given as a warning in the beginning. The way it was separated into 3 different modules was helpful though to keep it organized.
Keep it like it is! Loved professor Dollar and Vatsal!

Strengths of this course include the labs which were engaging and generally covered the real world applications showing how the class applied to everyday objects. Some weaknesses of the course include the lectures with example problems. These lectures were generally more freeform and occasionally the example problems would be skipped or the steps would be drawn live virtually so the lecture slides when looked back upon didn't show the work. A way to improve this could be having a solution plan in mind or pre-written on the slides so there's not as confusing of an example.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: virtual labs were run pretty well, would recommend taking this course in-person though as mechanical engineering really needs to be done in-person
It was difficult to fully grasp the design process and understand how a machine shop works while completely virtual
I think everything worked well!

The practices that succeeded were the virtual labs especially the power drill lab which was interesting to take apart and was engaging in the sense that we got to do it ourselves so it almost felt like an in-person lab. What could be improved are the example problems in the lectures which were hard to follow as they were drawn on the Zoom whiteboard.

The class was not very engaging due to lab being virtual, but in at least one lab we were given physical parts to disassemble which made it more interesting. More of this implementation would have been nice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are trying to decide on MechE as a major, or if you are just interested in the basics of design.
Good intro course. Not too hard.
if you're mech e. or want to learn some solidworks for whatever reason
I would definitely recommend this course as an introduction to mechanical engineering course to experience what the major looks like and gain very useful information for further studies in the area.
No I wouldnt

If you are set on majoring in mechanical engineering, then I recommend taking this class over ENAS 118. However, if you aren't sure what kind of engineering you want to do, I recommend taking ENAS 118. That said, the course content is a little dry and the professor does not seem to care much about teaching it. It's possible that this was due to the online format but, even so, the most useful knowledge that I got from this class was learning how to use Solidworks, which mostly happened during lab with the TF.
I would recommend this course to any student looking for an introduction to mechanical design because it covered interesting and important topics.
Yes if you are looking to see what kinds of things you will study in the mechanical engineering major.
Yes it was a good intro course.

I would recommend this course to another student if it is in-person as working in the shop combined with in-person labs seems like it could be a good experience and it is clear to see that the course does have some real-world applications to how things are made.
I would recommend the course but only in the case that it is in person and labs can be done.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture and a weekly virtual lab
also virtual labs
Live virtual lecture combined with live virtual lab sections.
Live virtual lecture and virtual lab.
Live, but recorded, lecture. There was also a virtual lab.
Live virtual lectures were always recorded and posted promptly, live virtual lab as well
Virtual lab.
I had a live virtual lecture twice a week and a virtual lab once a week.
live virtual lecture, plus a virtual lab.
